Author: CRAWFORD
Quote: Although many runholders came to regard the land they leased as their own, their occupancy was intended to be only a temporary using of waste land until it was required for closer settlement. Anyone - the runholder included - could buy the freehold of all or any part of a run at any time to establish a farm. However, some protection for runholders was essential, for they could not be expected to improve their runs if the land and improvements were in danger of being freeholded without warning by an outside buyer. Runholders were able to register with the Provincial Council improvements such as buildings, plantations, fencing, and yards, for which they were granted [246] an improvement pre-emptive right (i.P.R.) covering fifty acres of land surrounding the improvement. A homestead pre-emptive right (H.P.R.), which afforded protection for 250 acres, could also be registered. ... One H.P.R. could be taken out for each property and it was only businesslike that each runholder should use this right to secure 250 acres around his homestead against purchase by an outsider. An H.P.R. was initially intended to cover the owner's or manager's home, but, in the case of runs of over 5,000 acres, could be extended to cover an outstation.

Author: POLACK
Quote: Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called para[as-acute] paraua[a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale, mungu nui (black physeter); right whale, tohora (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark, mango (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes.

haeremai, as this is included in the Dictionary, haerera also should be included, the former being the response to the latter. ibid. 55/151 haerera,term of farewell, said by the one who stays to the one who goes: ra, an indefinite `yonder.' The reply by the departer is: e noho (lit. sit still), or hei konei ra (for you this place).ibid. 151 haerera, term of farewell, said by the one who stays to the one who goes: ra, an indefinite `yonder.' The reply by the departer is: e noho (lit. sit still), or hei konei ra (for you this place).

The Exhumation, or hahunga, - i.e., cleaning of the bones, - sometimes took place a year after death.

Another matter touching on the recurring annoyance of vernacular names is that up till 1891 Lotella rhacinus was universally accepted as the hake: then, in 1912, Waite, for no apparent reason, transfers this name to Merluccius gayi, although he admits that the records of these fish were hopelessly mixed on the expedition. ...

Author: HUTTON
Quote: Lotella rhacinus= hake, with a note on its relationship to Physiculus bacchus. He calls Gadus australis (Hutton) the `haddock.'
Records Lotella rhacinus from the Chatham islands.
Gadus australis = haddock.

Author: SHERRiN
Quote: Lotella rhacinus = hake. Pseudophycis brevissculus = whiting. Reports Lotella rhacinus from the Chathams, after Hutton.

Pseudophycis sp. Noted as common, with remarks on variation of size and fins. Specimens sent to Hector. The spirit specimen (1) in the Museum is probably one of these, as it is labelled with Sandager's name.

Hake = Lotella rhacinus. ibid. 210 in report from Cape Maria van Diemen, where the terms `blue-fish' and `rock-cod' (Parapercis) are used together , i suspect that the former were specimens of Physiculus rhacinus, and this would extend the range a little.

This is where the confusion starts. He records Merluccius gayi (Guichenot)-syn. for Merlus gayi (Guich.) and Gadus australis (Hutton) - as the `hake,' and makes no independent record for Physiculus rhacinus, but admits that the records of the two fishes were in a state of hopeless confusion, thus tacitly admitting that specimens of both were recorded under the same name. LiTERATURE WiTH A SUMMARY OF THE DATA iN EACH CASE.

Author: POLACK
Quote: fn Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called para [as-acute] paraua [a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale, mungu nui (black physeter); right whale, tohora (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark, mango (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes.

Author: PARROTT
Quote: There is much confusion in the common names applied to New Zealand fishes, and the application of the name `Hake' to several distinct species of our fishes, is a good example of that confusion. in Blenheim, Nelson, Picton and Wellington, a very different fish, scientifically known as Rexea solandri, and closely related to the Barracouta, with obviously no affinities to the Cod family, is called `Hake' or `Southern Kingfish'. The name Hake applied to this fish is entirely wrong, as it belongs to the Snake Mackerel family, the Gempylidae. ibid. 154 SOUTHERN KiNGFiSH Rexea solandri (Cuv. & Val.) ... The Southern Kingfish is closely related to the Barracouta, and is known in the North island as the `hake' but this name is more accurately applied to a very different fish, Merlangius australis, which belongs to the true Cod family. ibid. 155 [Southern Kingfish, Rexea Solandri] is found also in southern Australian waters. in Sydney it is sold as `hake'. it is also known as `Hake' in Auckland and sometimes sold as `lemon-fish'. ibid. 170 Southern Kingfish Rexea solandri Hake

He is the Silver Kingfish, who is sometimes called Hake and known in Australia as Gemfish.

Quote: The Cloudy Bay cod (Lotella rhacinus), also known as rock cod and southern hake, is rather more brown and lacks the dark blotch by the pectoral fin. ibid. 1/898 HAKE is a name applied to several quite different marine fish in different parts of the country. The whiting or haddock, Merluccius australis, is a true hake, very similar to the North Sea species; it is, actually, often called English hake. it occurs in fairly deep water south of Cook Strait. The southern kingfish, Jordanidia solandri, is also known as hake: it is closely related and similar to the barracouta, and found throughout New Zealand. The Cloudy Bay cod, Lotella rhacinus, is sometimes known as southern hake.(see also Kingfish.)

Many legends are associated with the mythical bird "hokioi"... in the South and in some parts of the North island it is identical, apparently, with the "hakuwai" which has seven joints in its wing, lives in the sky, and presages trouble... "its cry was Hokioi! Hokioi! Hu!" The last word represented the whizzing sound made by the bird in flight.

Author: DEMPSEY
Quote: The Mysterious Ha-ka-wai Bird [heading] No-one has ever seen it, no-one knows what it is like. Mutton-birders who have heard the strange sound of its passing over the islands at night speak of the ha-ka-wai bird. A swish of wings close overhead, a sound like the rattle of chains when a boat lets the anchor down, again the sound of wingbeats and the cry floating earthward from the heavens, Ha-ka-wai! Ha-ka-wai! in a drawn-out singsong with accent on the first and last syllables.

A strange bird in Maori eyes is the hakuai of the off-shore islands in the far south. ... Whole families go mutton-birding ... At night the fowlers gather round their camp-fires, and old songs are sung ... and ghost-stories retold. And in the darkness sometimes they hear the ghost-bird screaming its `Haku-ai, haku-ai, Ooh!' and then a hair-raising swoosh of great wings ... This bird, called the `hakuai' from its call, is spoken of as a spirit. ... The mystery of the hakuai may be dispelled by assuming it to be ... the frigate-bird (Fregata aquila).

The Maori word hakuwai (or hakawai or hakuai, or any of at least five other variant spellings, including the European harkowhy) was defined by Williams in his Maori Dictionary as 'an extinct bird heard at night'.

Author: ANDERSON
Quote: it is a moot point whether the name hakuwai was derived from hokioi.. or whether hokioi has been adopted., as an imperfect rendition of hakuwai, to provide a name for the eagle legend.

Author: HARGREAVES
Quote: Half crown [:] half dollar, half bull

The crown was called a bull, a cartwheel, a caser, five bob, and most familiar of all a dollar, ... The half crown was called a half-dollar, a half-bull, half-caser, two-and-a-kick, and two-and-a-buck. in the latter instance buck stands for sixpence, though apparently this term was rarely used by itself for that coin denomination, but almost always in association with a number of shillings. The florin seems to have had fewer English nicknames, only two bob being recorded as being in use in New Zealand.
[uncertain cit]

it may have suited those who were favourable to the success of the "King movement" to conceal its real purport; while others, who have cherished so much affection for the natives or professed so much interest in their welfare, may have been blinded to the inevitable results of encouraging such dangerous aspirations among the half-savage chiefs and tribes ...

Halfbred sheep. Originally only applied to a sheep by a longwool ram from a merino ewe, but now loosely applied to the type. Corriedale sheep were originally called inbred hb. Now in-bred hb. flocks are those which reintroduce merino or longwool blood, while he Corrie- dale flocks can only introduce Corriedale blood. (C.)

This term [Half-bred] covers: (1) the progeny of any distinct breed of long-woolled ram mated with merino ewes; (2) the progeny of merino rams mated with any breed of long-woolled ewe; (3) the progeny from the mating of half-bred with half-bred. The wool produced by sheep from the above crossing is termed `half-bred' and ranges from 48's to 56's quality.

The half crown was called a half-dollar, a half-bull, half-caser, two-and-a-kick, and two-and-a-buck. in the latter instance buck stands for sixpence, though apparently this term was rarely used by itself for that coin denomination, but almost always in association with a number of shillings. [34] This name is applied both to the skipper (Scombresox Forsteri) and to the ihi or half-beak, which are allied fishes representing those of the same names in the British seas. The representatives of the former genus, however, though common in England, appear to be rare in these seas, while the half-beak, which is of rare occurrence in the British seas, is common all round New Zealand, and is the ordinary gar-fish that is so highly appreciated, especially in Auckland and Dunedin. ibid. 40 HALF-BEAK (see GAR FiSH).

Sheep dog.- Dog to work sheep; collie (q.v.). S.ds. run naturally either to bring sheep towards you or to drive them away; and when a puppy shows his preference he is broken in for that work. The dogs that bring sheep are called heading ds. (q.v.) and most of these can be taught to lead (q.v.) if desired. Dogs which take to driving sheep away are broken in to huntaway and are called htwys (q.v.). Some dogs will both hd. and htwy and are called handy ds. They are not generally high-class heading dogs but very useful about hand and sometimes very useful mustering dogs. Some men have a special slewing d., but a well-trained, hdg. dog or htwy. will usually slew (q.v.). (C.)

Author: NEWTON

HANDY DOG: A dog which can do both heading and huntaway work. A good one is a champion indeed.

Author: TUCKER
Quote: in our ranks was a very hard-headed gentleman by the name of Jensen who, on arriving at the pub, breasted up to the bar and ordered a `hangman's blood'. The barman confessed total ignorance of just what this drink might comprise. He was told to produce a beer handle, which he did, and was then ordered to go along [17] the entire length of the bar, putting in one nip of whatever spirits were on display. Now at that time spirits were very hard to come by, but Paul Rabone, the proprietor of the Mangatara Hotel, seemed to have an inexhaustible supply. Doing as he was bid the barman proceeded from one end to the other, putting in such things as scotch, gin, bacardi, rum, creme de menthe, and so on. He finally returned to the prospective quaffer of this incredible beverage with the beer mug about quarter-full of a purplish looking liquid. `Now,' said Jensen, `Fill it up with beer.'

The fishing off the island is very good, there being abundance of hapuku, kokiri, kohikohi, maumau [sic], schnapper, kahawai, tarakihi, in addition to plenty of shell-fish such as koura or crayfish, crabs, paua, etc. The mako shark, so well known for its beautiful teeth, which are highly prized by the Maoris as ornaments, is found off this island and nowhere else in the world i believe, ...
The fish for eating are hapuka,Oligorus gigas; rock cods, Percis colias ; tarakihi, Chilodactylus macropterus ; moki, Latris ciliaris , etc.,etc.

Author: SHERRiN
Quote: HAPUKU (Oligorus gigas). The first on the list of marketable fishes is the hapuku, or whapuku of the Maoris ( Hectoria gigas of Count Castelnau), or habuka, as the name is generally pronounced by Europeans, who in the south, apply the name groper to the same fish. it is also occasionally called the cod-fish, which is altogether erroneous, as it is more properly the representative of the sea-perch of European seas.

Of the sea-fishes that are used as food in New Zealand, we have among the constant residents on all parts of our coast the hapuku, tarakihi, trevally, moki, aua, rock-cod, wrasse, and patiki; and while the snapper, mullet, and gurnet are only met with in the north, the trumpeter, butterfish, and red-cod are confined to the south.

A hatch tent consists of a large, light tarpaulin which is lashed down round the hatch coaming while its centre is held up by a wire strung fore-and-aft across the hold. it provides effective temporary cover for an open hold, saving the time and labour required to replace the more cumbersome permanent hatch covers.

Author: BATHGATE
Quote: Hatter: Whatever the origin of the phrase, `as mad as a hatter' can have been, i have often unsuccessfully endeavoured to discover. But doubtless it is from this phrase that the name of hatter has come to be applied in mining parlance, to one who works alone or without a mate. There are always a few of these unsocial miners about every digging, and their solitariness arises from every imaginable cause. Frequently they are misanthropes, sometimes placid contented creatures, who, so long as they can make a living by `fossicking' about, are happy. / [139]. My host was a hatter and he always kept a spare stretcher for any chance passer-by.

Author: MAY
Quote: HATTER: a solitary, a digger who works alone. The derivation of this New Zealand expression is obscure. Archdeacon Harper described the hatters as `men who live and work by themselves, often old sailors and much travelled men, content with the solitude of well-kept huts, a few books, hard work, their dog as companion, perhaps some poultry, and a weekly visit on Saturdays to the townships to sell their gold and see friends. Whence the term `hatter' i have never discovered; maybe because such solitaries are regarded as `mad as a hatter'. Another possibility is suggested by the remark that the hatter `kept his whole world under his hat'.

Hatter. One who works and camps by himself. Originally a miner's expression, no doubt from the saying of a man without relations that he had `all his family under his hat'. Archdeacon Harper derived the word from `mad as a hatter' (Letters, p. 143). The word is in general use on stations. H.'s billy, tent, etc., one just large enough for one man. Sergeant: `He says the man was mad, your Worship.' Witness: `No, i didn't. i said he was either drunk or ratty.'
`He's just got a spite on me,' she told the Bench with tears in her voice, and referring to Mr. Blank. `The other woman was right; he's just got a spite on the poor people ...'
Black Sir John Findlay - Mr Findlay - has got a spite on me over the Parnell election. Sir John Not at all, Mr Black. You are here to get money out of my clients and it is my duty to protect them.

Author: PARTRiDGE
Quote: Have for breakfast. occ. before breakfast (as a rare appetiser). A humorous way of implying that a thing is easy to do, (gen.) a man easy to beat. E.g. `Why! i have one like him every day before breakfast' or `i could have or done with six like him for breakfast.' For task or feat, the before breakfast, often with do or have, is preferred. C. 20 coll.: mostly Australia and New Zealand.

Author: McGiLL
Quote: breakfast in phr. have for breakfast find some person or thing easy to overcome or achieve; eg `Just let him try anything. i'll have him for breakfast.' NZA mostly.

Of the three species recognized, two, the quail-hawk (Harpae Novae Zealandiae) and the bush-hawk (H. ferox) [or sparrow-hawk], belong to a genus peculiar to New Zealand. [The third is the New Zealand harrier, Circus Gouldi, also found in Australia.]
Nesierax novaehollandiae Gm. Quail-hawk. Of our debatable two species of falcons, the larger one, of which we now treat, is undoubtedly the rarer.

Author: ADAM
Quote: With flat rosettes of hairy leaves and creeping stems, hawkweed is abundant in dry tussock grassland in the South island hill country. ... Botanical name: Hieracium aurantiacum, Central Europe. Family: Compositae.
...the open pastures, with scattered plants of low stature, were vulnerable to invasion by rabbits, hawkweed (Hieracium spp.) and, in the driest areas, native scabweed.
Erosion became widespread, and introduced weeds such as hawkweed (Hieracium spp.) thrived.

"The invasion of Hieracium hawkweed in our convenant was a major issue for me."... With Brian Molloy's help, he discovered that his practice of keeping the stock off the land in summer was allowing the hawkweed to flower and spread.

Having been settled and stocked with sheep since the mid-1800s, much of the land between the Awatere Valley and Hanmer had been devastated by intensive grazing, rabbits and burn-offs, which exacerbated erosion, and encourage the spread of weeds such as sweet briar, hawkweed and broom, all of which remained a problem.

in more recent years Hieracium species - various dandelion-like hawkweeds - have been a major problem. The silvery grey rosettes of hawkweed form a skin across the land (often when over-grazed by a combination of sheep and rabbit) inhibiting the regrowth of both introduced pasture and native plants. [hawke weed]

Much of the land seems to have been badly sown down, as there are many poor swards, and plenty of hawke weed as you pass along to Toko. The hawke weed and the ox-eye daisy are here as at Stratford. 2.

in the furrow method of irrigation small furrows or corrugations are made in the direction of the slope and connected with a head-ditch supplying water .. Water is taken from the head-ditch, which follows approximately the contour of the surface, into the distributing-furrows, which may be parallel with the ditch or diverge from it. in turning the water from the head-ditch into the furrows the common practice in Central Otago is to make openings in the lower bank with a shovel.
One of the most frequent and heaviest operations in the preparation of land for irrigation is the formation of head-ditches.

Author: McLiNTOCK
Quote: Heading. in the long head the competitor stands with his dog in a ring (1 chain in diameter) facing a hillside near the top of which three sheep are set loose. When time is called the dog is dispatched, either on a left-hand or a right-hand cast, up the hill for some 800 yards to a point behind the sheep. On command the dog `lifts' the sheep and, keeping them together, `pulls' them in a direct line back to his master in the ring. To allow the dog to show complete control over the sheep, the run ends with a `hold in the ring'. This involves stopping the sheep in the ring and holding them there. The first stages of the short head are much the same, but over half the distance, 400 yards. At the point where the sheep reach the shepherd, man and dog must drive them ahead down a `drive' which is 60 yards long and 1 chain wide and defined by short poles, to a set of hurdles which are 9 ft apart and parallel with the line of the drive. The sheep are driven between the hurdles and then down a second drive, similar to the first, to the pen or yard, which is 6 ft square. After opening one side, the competitor must stand by the pen gate until the sheep are yarded. The dog must do virtually all the work and his master's right of movement and intervention are strictly limited.
Bords, or headings, are tunnels driven in the coal. ... lead off on both sides from the heading or main drive.

After the All Blacks had beaten Wales in the first match of their grand slam, i was startled to find a sports writer lambasting commentator Murray Mexted for applying the word "heady" to rugby, when "heady", in his view, only meant things like "intoxicating" etc. News to me. Phrases like "He plays a heady game" or He's a heady player" have been in New Zealand sporting vocabulary all my life, meaning "thinking, intelligent, or analytical".
Mex Files: "He's always been a heady player." - Murray Mexted may have been trying to describe Leon McDonald as "intoxicating, impetuous, or overbearing". Or he might simply have got the wrong word.

The herd-testing movement is worthy of special mention. Practically 20 per cent. of the dairy cows in the Dominion are tested for butter-fat production monthly during the milking season. ibid. 346 Although herd testing and milk recording societies existed in Germany, Denmark, England and other countries many years earlier, systematic herd testing appears to have been first developed in New Zealand about the year 1920, when a model Herd Testing Association was established by the New Zealand Department of Agriculture in the Wairarapa.

Author: POWDRELL
Quote: Herd-testing. - it is strongly maintained that herd-testing - the periodical recording of the weight of each cow's produce together with a butter-fat test from which data the production of the cow for the period is calculated - is the surest way of distinguishing the drones ...

As the result of herd testing, greater attention to culling and breeding and improved farm management, the average butterfat yield per cow increased from 154.25 lbs. per annum in 1920-21 to 218.80 lbs. per annum in 1929-30. ibid. 345 The major function of Herd Testing is primarily to determine the milk and butterfat producing ability of individual cows, and from this information to secure accurate data for the elimination of low-producing cows and also to provide a more scientific basis for the breeding of dairy stock.

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Quote: A cow with `a good test', that is, milk rich in butterfat, may be more valuable than another cow that gives more milk. About 1910 the practice rose of smpling milk from all the cows in a herd individually and testing the milk for its fat content. This process is called herd-testing. ... it is still not decided whether the word is hyphenated or not. i find it without a hyphen in a publication of the Department of Agriculture in 1950, with a hyphen in a textbook of dairying in 1955. Pronunciation is with one stress, on herd. ibid. 149 in New Zealand, everyone uses the term herd-testing, not milk-testing, because everyone thinks of the dairy industry from a producer's, not a consumer's, point of view.
Herd testing helps farmers to maintain the standard of their herds - it shows up the lower producers so that they can be culled from the herd.

The back country of New Zealand contains a heritage of about 1400 huts that is unequalled anywhere in the world. These huts were built for the following reasons: wild animal control (~750) sheep mustering (~500) recreation (~150) a range of other purposes including prospecting, scientific studies and castaway sustenance. Others began life as schools and homes and later became huts. These huts have heritage value as the only physical remnant of these activities. ... DOC is identifying a representative selection of key historic huts that can be managed long term to conserve this heritage and allow its appreciation. it is intended to have interpretation signs provided for each historic hut.

The New Zealand Weed and Pest Control society in recent publication `Standard common Names For weeds in New Zealands' records the name cow parsnip without giving the specific name. This plant could be H. sphondlylium a native of the British isle and at one time widely advocated as a suitable stock food because of its thick fleshy tap root. Hogweed in New Zealand is a popular descriptive name for four different weeds. Two of these, namely the twin cress and wart cress, belong to the same genus. The other two are the wild portulaca and wire weed, which are in no way related. The popular names of the latter illustrate how confusing the use of names like fire weed or wandering willie can be as a means of identifying weeds and plants. These common names of plants frequently have only local significance and in cases may even become obsolete. For this reason botanical names are ...

Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Quote: Ages of sheep. Although there are many variations, the following names are usually used: A sheep is a lamb until weaned. After weaning a lamb is called a hogget until shorn. A male lamb is a ram lamb until castrated, then a wether. A female lamb is a ewe lamb. After shearing, a ewe or ram lamb is usually called a shorn hogget until cutting the first two teeth. it is then called a two-tooth. Some use the term two-tooth as soon as the lamb is shorn. Next year the sheep is a four-tooth, then a six-tooth and then an eight-tooth or full-mouthed sheep. it is full-mouthed as long as the teeth remain perfect but then becomes broken-mouthed and gummy

The hokio, says Williams, is 'the messenger bird'. Hokio, the verb 'to descend', is also 'a bird, probably the same as hokioi, with variant spellings of hakuai and hokiwai ... an extint bird of nocturnal habits, held in superstitious regard by the Maori, said to be never seen.
The Hokio is a spiritual messenger bird and, because all things arise out of sacredness, the source of which is God, everything is sacred.

Many legends are associated with the mythical bird "hokioi"... in the South and in some parts of the North island it is identical, apparently, with the "hakuwai" which has seven joints in its wing, lives in the sky, and presages trouble... "its cry was Hokioi! Hokioi! Hu!" The last word represented the whizzing sound made by the bird in flight.

There's the varying shades of black, brown and grey with a wee dash of white on the forehead and a white tip on the tail...'They're just different,' he says. 'Things like positioning of bones and teeth, everything from the traditional farm animal breeding world, you can forget about when it comes to Hokonuis. They're as tough as old boots and interesting in their grazing habits. They prefer rough feed and will eat heads and thistles before they touch the clover.'..interested though he is, there's no way Peter will reduce the Coopworth flock in concession to the Hokonuis.

The first record of the feral Hokonuis was in 1863, a flock of about 200 animals, so they have had 150 years to adapt. The Hokonuis' ancestors are believed to be smooth-skinned Saxony Merinos .. When and how Hokonuis came to be here is unlikely to be proven.

included in Hodges's study is the truly macho battle of alcoholic consumption - the drinking game. ... Other well-known [drinking] games are Hokonui Swindle, Bottles, Fluffy Ducks, Bunnies are Hovering, Cardinal Huff, All Blacks, Matches, and The Amazing Grimaldi Brothers. All these games involve either a complicated intellectual exercise, tongue twisters, mathematical calculations or aerobatics in a confined space; High Candelabras for example, involves intoxicated individuals attempting to traverse the four walls of a room without touching the floor.

Baker identified the Hokitika version as based on a method of counting `whereby the person who calls a certain number in a sequence pays a specified sum into the jackpot'. Glenn Johnston defines the Hokonui version as a drinking game that combines elements of chance with the ability to hold your liquor and follow a few simple rules - though the deviousness of the caller can also influence proceedings. The aims are simple: to liven things up, get a bit of alcohol consumed quickly and sort the stayers from the pikers.

Author: SUTTON-SMiTH
Quote: There is only one record of a New Zealand game in which a formal penalty element entered. This was a game of marbles called Dumps and was played at Wakefield in 1875. in this game the loser, in a marble game of Holey, was required to hold his marble partially exposed between the fingers of his closed fist [for others to shoot at].

Author: SUTTON-SMiTH
Quote: in the nineteenth century the ring game seems to have been the most popular marble game. (in more recent years marble games with holes have had the greater role.) There was Big Ring, in which a circle a yard or more in diameter was drawn on the ground; there was the mullibar variation, in which an outsize taw was catapulted amongst the marbles in this circle. There were Little Ring, Liney, Follows, Follow the Taw, Holey, and then, on a less important scale, Butcher's Board, in which the marbles were bowled through the holes in a board, Eye-Drop, Knock-Backs, Leggings-Out (or Leggin's-Out), Span-'Em, and Backits. The last was more usually a girls' game.

Author: KEiTH & MAiN
Quote: ] [Photo caption] Marbles became `in' or `out' capriciously but someome always knew the rules of the various games - `holey,' `liney' and, seen here, `ringey' - which could be played for `funs' or `keeps.'

Author: SUTTON-SMiTH
Quote: Of the Help-He games, Kick the Tin, is the most widely known. A tin is placed in the centre of a circle. One He is in charge of the tin. He can only tag the other players when his tin is in the centre of the circle. Any players he catches must stay in the circle. Any non-caught player can help and free the other caught players by running through the circle and kicking the tin out of it. Other names for this game are: Kick the Boot (Gisborne [18]90), Knock the Block or Homaiacky (Nelson [18]95), Kick the football or Piacky (Mangatainoka).

Author: SUTTON-SMiTH
Quote: in a few tagging games the players joined hands with the He when they were caught and helped him catch the other players. These games were known as The Bellahonie (E-21) (Wellington, 1910), Kick Post One (Hampden, Otago, 1880), and Ballyhooley (Wellington, 1920). More popular were those games in which the players helped one another to fight the He, and of these the most widespread was the game known as Kick the Tin (e-3), Kick the Boot, Kick the Block, or Homiacky. in this game the He was put on guard of a jam tin placed inside a small circle marked on the ground. [Other players hid: those He could see he named and tapped the tin three times and `captured': other hiders waited till they had chance to kick tin out of circle: then all were free again.]

The Home Guard has atrtracted little attention from historians... There was nothing glamorous about the Home Guard... it was nearly a year after war was declared that the War Cabinet finally laid plans for the formation of a volunteer Home Guard, to comprise men who were too old or to young to serve overseas, or who were being kept at home in essential occupations... The urgency and seriousness of the war eventually forced Home Guard units to be set up in almost every settlement and town in the country... The Home Guard in New Zealand eventually numbered 12,000 in its ranks.

i move, That the House take note of the report of the Justice and Law Reform Committee on the Crimes (Home invasion) Amendment Bill... Home invasion is not an everyday offence.

The definition of home invasion.. is intended to cover all situations where an offender commits an offence in the process of entering, while inside, and while leaving, places where people live. in the bill as introduced, a home invasion must occur in a "dwellinghouse"... The definition of "dwellinghouse" is.. .intended to encompass the variety of places in which people can live, including caravans, mobile homes and other structures. it focuses on the use to which a building is put, and is therefore not intended to include buildings or parts of buildings that have some other primary purpose, such as a commercial buildings or hospitals... 17A.. 'Dwellinghouse' means (a) a building or other structure, or part of a building or other structure, that is used by the occupant principally as a residence; or (b) A mobile home, caravan, or houseboat, that is used by the occupant principally as a residence; "Home invasion", when used in the expression 'the offence involved home invasion'.. means that the person who committed the offence did so... (a) While breaking and entering, or otherwise unlawfully entering, an occupied dwellinghouse; or (b) While in an occupied dwellinghouse, after having broken and entered, or otherwise unlawfully entered, the dwellinghouse; or (c) While breaking out of an occupied dwellinghouse; or (d) While otherwise unlawfully in an occupied dwellinghouse

Author: BEATTiE
Quote: The custom in the old days was to call the buildings on a run `the station,' and the land that went with it was `the run.' On a big property you could find several `stations,' and the principal one was called `the home station,' while the others were `out-stations.' This was the old Australian usage which was carried over to New Zealand at first, but gradually the signification was altered by loosely calling the whole run a station, and then the real station became a homestead and the out-stations became shepherds' huts. in this present book it will be noticed that generally the writer has preserved the olden custom of calling the main buildings the station and the land the run. The runs over in Australia being, as a rule, much larger than those in New Zealand, the `station' and `out-station' phraseology was preserved much longer than over here, where even in advertisements in the late 'fifties we see the English word `homestead' ousting the colonial word `station.'

Author: BEATTiE
Quote: it is usually understood that in the early days the word `station' denoted the owner's house and its immediate buildings, while `run' meant the whole property. Strange to say, i only noted the word `station' twice, and each time with a diverse meaning. On July 21, 1865, the diary says: `Sold 17 head of cattle - remaining on station 15 head.' Then on September 11, 1865, we read: `Wilkinson returned to the Home Station.' The first of these entries means the whole run - the second the homestead or main buildings.

Author: BEATTiE
Quote: The custom in the old days was to call the buildings on a run `the station,' and the land that went with it was `the run.' On a big property you could find several `stations,' and the principal one was called `the home station,' while the others were `out-stations.' This was the old Australian usage which was carried over to New Zealand at first, but gradually the signification was altered by loosely calling the whole run a station, and then the real station became a homestead and the out-stations became shepherds' huts. in this present book it will be noticed that generally the writer has preserved the olden custom of calling the main buildings the station and the land the run. The runs over in Australia being, as a rule, much larger than those in New Zealand, the `station' and `out-station' phraseology was preserved much longer than over here, where even in advertisements in the late 'fifties we see the English word `homestead' ousting the colonial word `station.'

No portion of the land occupied by a holder of a pasturage license whereon a homestead shall have been erected or improvements made shall be offered for sale until the offer of purchasing such land shall have been made to such license-holder at a price per acre assessed within the limits of the upset price of the class of land to which the land in particular may belong. [Marginal note: Homestead to be offered to license holder previously to sale].

it shall be lawful for the Board to permit the original holder of a pastoral license.. to apply for and purchase in one block.. an allotment of land not exceeding three hundred and twenty acres on which to erect buildings, yards, or such other improvements as may be necessary for working the run. [Marginal note: Licensee may purchase land on run for homestead].

Wherever a lessee or licensee has erected a homestead on the land included in his lease or license, he shall have the right, with the consent of the Board, to select and occupy, during the currency ofhis lease or license, an area of not exceeding in the whole one hundred and fifty acres adjacent to such homestead, which shall be exempt from the right of determination as provided in section onehundred and seventy.

Where a lessee or licensee of a run exceeding five thousand acres in area has erected a homestead on the land included in his lease or license, he shall have the right, with the consent of the Board, to select and occupy, during the currency of his lease or license, an area of not exceeding in the whole one hundred and fifty acres adjacent to such homestead, which shall be exempt from the right of determination as provided in section onehundred and ninety-two.

The Minister may from time to time direct the Board to negotiate with any owner of private lands.. for the purchase or exchange of any lands.. For the acquisition of sites for homesteads for neighbouring high-lying pastoral land.
Private land may.. be acquired on behalf of Her Majesty under this Act for any of the following purposes.. Providing land as sites for homesteads for neighbouring pastoral land.

Homestead. in the old days the owner's residence, but only if it was some distance from the rest of the station buildings (see big house). when the Goverment began cutting up the runs in the 'nineties, they or their surveyors adopted the word to signify what had been formerly called the station, and the new settlers followed them, so that the new sense of the word is now widely used. Butler and Sir F. Weld also use it in the modern sense, but in writing for Englishmen. (C.R.)

Quote: ~ slang term for compensation, payment, money; characteristic corruption of Maori Utu(q.v.).

`There are several specimens of bush slang transplanted from the Maori language. `Hoot' is a very frequent synonym for money or wage. i have heard a shearer at the Pastoralist Union office in Sydney when he sought to ascertain the scale of remuneration, enquire of the gilt-edged clerk behind the barrier, `What's the hoot, mate?' The Maori equivalent for money is utu, pronounced by the Ngapuhi and other northern tribes with the last syllable clipped, and the word is very largely used by the kauri-gum diggers and station hands in the North island. The original meaning of first settled in New Zealand, they found that the savage inhabitants had no conception of any recompense except the grim recompense of blood. Under Christianizing influences the natives were induced to forego the blood-revenge for injuries, on receiving a solatium in goods or land, and so utu came to have the double meaning of revenge and recompense, and eventually became recognized as the Maori word for money.'

Author: H W ORSMAN
Quote: A. Maori contexts. Orig. a European rendering of the Maori noun utu, return (for anything ); satisfaction, ransom, reward, price, reply' (Williams); not to be used confused with uto `revenge', a confusion evident in many of the explanations of the meaning of utu). The word widely used was in all the above senses by Europeans who had dealings with Maoris, from the general `return for work, injury, etc.' to the concrete `money' it is often found constructed with the definite article `the utu, hutu' etc. translating the original Maori indefinite article, or adjective `some' he utu `an utu, some utu'. (Occas. constr with indef. article, see 1834). in later European usage the definite article was dropped to conform to English idiom eg' `give me the hoot' becomes `give me (some) hoot' The following is perhaps a `transitional' use 1828 C Davis journal Colenso Papers 3/18) `Another chief had been killed as a utu or payment'. (is this [ei utu] reflecting Maori [(h)e utu], as well as English a for an?). The phonology, resulting in the English hoot, parallels that of toot from tutu, with the final unvoiced [u] not being heard by English ears. The initial [h] derives perhaps from a syncopation of [he utu]; but more prob. from the var. or error noted on p. 4 of 1842: Maunsell Grammar of the New Zealand Language (4th ed) 1894: `in pronouncing u, the speaker will have to guard against the error of those who prefix the aspirate when no aspirate is admissable. According to the u, utu, etc., are pronounced as if spelt hu, hutu.'.

Source: Book of New Zealand, A (J.C. Reid)

Quote: it is often assumed that the phrase [sc. the "House of Pain"] came to be applied by visiting teams because of the perceived difficulty of winning at Carisbrook. it actually began, however, in the late 1980s within the Otago team when players referred to Carisbrook as the House of Pain, because of exhausting training sessions. it was once attributed to an Otago player of the time, Brent Pope, and he happily claimed the credit for it, but it's difficult to pin down to one person. it's only in recent years that it's been seen as the House of Pain for visiting teams - a belief encouraged by Radio Sport (which began in 1998) commentators who had little or no acquaintance with either the ground or the phrase.

More recently, the two types have merged, and today the Maori children, who are mainly responsible for perpetuating the game in New Zealand, include in their games movements borrowed from the European tradition. ... in most of the provinces the game was known as Knucklebones, and it is widely reported as having been played by New Zealand children of European origin until about 1900. Occasionally it was known as Chucks, Chuckstones, Chuckystones, Fingerstones, Hucklebones, Jacks, Jackstones, Knuckles, or Knucklestones. Children still played it here and there throughout the country in 1949, but they knew little about it until plastic knuckles were imported in 1954 in large quantities and revived the game.

Author: PiCKERiNG
Quote: So to cope with the rituals of tramping, its pains and camaraderie, a slang language has developed to suit. Lots of quick short words to fit in the breathless pauses as you pant uphill. `Crud' (cloud), `bush-bash', a `gunn' tramper (which must have originated from Davy Gunn's famous trek up the Hollyford Valley to help victims of a plane crash in1936; he travelled 40 km by rowing boat, horse and foot in 21 hours), `windfall' (a collapsed pile of trees), `pit' (the tramper's true friend, a sleeping bag), `pog' (porridge), `bastard grass' and `lawyer' (two unpleasant plants), `piker' (one who stayed home), `Huey' (all-powerful god of weather), and many, many more. ibid. 46 New Zealand weather, sometimes called `Huey', is fast and fickle, with abrupt and noisy changes of mood.

The derisive phrases, `Send it down, Hughie' and `Let it come down, Hughie', go back to early in this century and are variants of the British military catch-phrase `Send it down, David'. `Send her down, Hughie', common in Australia's droughty climate, may not be so derisive. Author: PARTRiDGE
Quote: send her down, Hughie! (and ..., Steve!) This Australian - hence also New Zealand - c.p. of late C19-20, the Steve variant being used during WW1, expresses a fervent desire for rain. (AS.) Variations of the next, her for it being characteristically Australian. send it down, David (with variant Davy lad)! The variant belongs to the Regular Army: and the basic send it down, David is often intensified by the addition of a repetitive send it down: late C19-20. in the army. esp. during WW1, it was used to implore David, the Welsh patron saint, to send a preferably very heavy shower, notably when it might cause a parade to be postponed or cancelled. Parts of Wales have a notoriously wet climate: and, what is more, Wales is the `Land of Leeks' (leaks). Both F & G and B & P are eloquent about this cp.
hughie n. NZ & Austral. joc. god controlling the weather (send her down, Hughie!). [pet-form of name Hugh]

This flax is also made use of for laying up ropes, lines, &c. The superior dress called Kaitaka[a2-a3-acute], is made from silken flax, (hunga hunga[as-acute].)

Author: LiNDSAY
Quote: in Otago the general name of the [flax] plant, as a whole, is `Korari,' - or as metamorphosed by the settler, pronounced and spelt `Kouradi,' [a-macron] or `Coradi' [a-macron]. The same term is applied in the North island equally to the whole plant, and to the dried flower-stem when cut for rafts or other purposes; or exclusively to the flower-stalk. in the North [83] island, the Flax-plant is also known as `Harakeke,' or `Herekiakia,' - its usual name there. ... The lower part of the flower-stem is `Kaikaha;' the outer part of the leaf `Parakoka;' [a1, o-macron] the refuse of the leaf `Hunga-hunga;' the flax, dressed or not, or scraped fibre, manufactured from the leaf, `Whitau,' or `Muka.'
Hungerfine: Ultra fine wool induced by starvation.

Author: McLiNTOCK
Quote: Huntaway. in both huntaway classes three sheep are set loose at the foot of the hill. While the shepherd remains at the bottom, his dog, working and barking to command, hunts the sheep upwards on a defined line away from his master. in the zig-zag hunt, the sheep are directed through three sets of flags 1 chain apart and spaced equally up the hill on a zig-zag course of approximately 440 yards. The course for the straight hunt is about the same length, from the foot of the hill up to and through a set of flags 1 chain apart.

Author: McGiLL

A huntaway should be a free-running dog, noisy, and under good command, and should lose points for not taking directions readily, insufficient noise, being too rash or too slow, and not keeping the sheep on a good course.

Author: CARR
Quote: A new hand ... is wise investing in a good huntaway or a heading dog. He can practice [sic] on the `killers' i.e. the sheep kept handy for station use, or better still, a good noisy yard dog, as all station hands are liable to be called upon to assist in drafting, etc.

Huntaway.A dog whose work is to drive sheep forward when mustering. As a verb the word is used in two sense, illustrated in the sentences: `That dog hunts away well' and `i hunt away with that dog.' (C.)

Sheep dog.- Dog to work sheep; collie (q.v.). S.ds. run naturally either to bring sheep towards you or to drive them away; and when a puppy shows his preference he is broken in for that work. The dogs that bring sheep are called heading ds. (q.v.) and most of these can be taught to lead (q.v.) if desired. Dogs which take to driving sheep away are broken in to huntaway and are called htwys (q.v.). Some dogs will both hd. and htwy and are called handy ds. They are not generally high-class heading dogs but very useful about hand and sometimes very useful mustering dogs. Some men have a special slewing d., but a well-trained, hdg. dog or htwy. will usually slew (q.v.). (C.)

Author: RENNiE
Quote: The Beardie was developed as a barking dog because in some parts of Scotland, particularly in the Western Highlands, much of the ground is covered with bracken, which combined with the deep gullies known as corries, makes it impossible for a heading dog to see his sheep. Here the shepherd has to get out above the sheep and more or less chase them out of the thick cover. These dogs were known as hunters, and it is presumably an adaptation of this name which led to the designation, huntaway. At the turn of the century there were four well known strains of huntaways about North Canterbury and Marlborough - the Clown, Rag, Borderglen's Rose and Pollock's Old Clyde breeds. Of these the Clown strain certainly had Beardie blood, believed to have been started with a half Beardie brought out from Scotland.

Author: REED
Quote: `hurdy-gurdy' [is a hand gum-washing machine, turned by a handle] -->[See also Reed Story of Kauri Gum]

Author: REED
Quote: The machine age on the gumfield appears to have been heralded as early as 1915 when an ingenious digger, whose name has unfortunately been forgotten, introduced what came to be known as the `hurdy-gurdy' or `gurdy.' ... [83] in its simplest form it was a tub, or a section of a small galvanised iron tank, the bottom perforated with small holes. in the centre stood a strong, revolving, upright shaft, to the lower part of which was attached a wooden paddle, extending on both sides of the shaft, almost to the sides of the tank. The top of the revolving shaft was fitted with a horizontal handle, enabling the paddle to be swung to and fro in a half-circle. This simple machine was usually operated by two men; a supply of gum-bearing dirt having been put into the tank, buckets of water were thrown in by one man while the other vigorously turned the shaft handle this way and that, stirring up the soil while the muddy water flowed out through the perforations.

Source: My Little State Home in Suburbia

Hut (h&ubreve.t), n. [Add.] 2. A house for shearers or other labourers on a station; as, the men's hut, there shearers' hut. This is sometimes a large, permanent structure of wood, brick, or stone. -->1898 Morris AE 207 Hut, n the cottage of a shepherd or a miner. The word is English but is especially common in Australia, and does not there connote squalor or meanness. The `Men's Hut' on a station is the building occupied by the male employees. [1844]
[a tramping hut] The accommodation at the Routeburn Hut, although plain, is quite satisfactory. The hut consists of three rooms furnished with wooden bunks, tables, shelves, and forms ..
hut n. the building on the sheep station where the shearers live, often a large stone building.-hut'-keep v.t. to look after the hut of a miner, shepherd, etc.

Author: BEATTiE
Quote: He [the pioneer pastoralist] has built a domicile of some sort, be it of canvas, calico, bagging, sticks, ferntrees, grass, slabs, mud, clay, stone, or wattle and daub. He may call it various names according to its materials, but three names would not enter his head - i.e., crib, back, or shack. He may call it a cabin, a shanty, a cottage, a warrie [whare], but probably he would use the commonest term of all - hut.

Author: BEATTiE
Quote: There is a danger of all writers about the old days using modern terms which were not used in the period they were writing about, and i have always tried to steer clear of this pit. Young writers are particularly prone to go astray in this matter, and we see talk of pioneer shacks in Otago, using a modern Canadian word, where an Otago pioneer would have said hut or warrie.

Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Quote: Hut. House where the station hands or shearers live. Some call it a whare. Until the 1930s and 40s the men usually ate, cooked and slept in a one-roomed hut with a fireplace at one end and bunks in tiers around the walls. Often there were no facilities for washing other than the creek. Today most huts are quite comfortable, with separate rooms for eating and sleeping, showers and toilets.
indeed, accommodation in the European Alps lies closer to the hotel end of the shelter spectrum than the tin cans we call huts in the Southern Alps.

Jack's Hut, near the summit of Arthur's Pass, is a rare surviving example of the roadmen's huts that dotted New Zealand's highest altitude main highway. Each roadman was responsible for maintaining a section of the road - clearing slips, filling in potholes - and lived with his family in a hut along his stretch.

Author: JONES

There are five men sleeping in the hut. i sleep in a bunk on one side of the fire, Mr. Haast ... sleeps upon the opposite one; my bullock-driver and hut-keeper have two bunks at the far end of the hut, along the wall; ... The usual mutton and bread for breakfast with a pudding made of flour and water baked in the camp-oven after a joint of meat - Yorkshire pudding, but without eggs. While we were at breakfast, a robin perched on the table and sat there a good while pecking at the sugar.

A HiGH COURT jury was told by Crown counsel Justin Smith in Wellington yesterday of a hire purchase `hydraulic deal' - a transaction, in which a hire purchase agreement stated a deposit had been paid whereas, in fact, it had not. ... Mr Smith said that during the trial the jury would hear about what was known colloquially as a `hydraulic deal'. This was a situation where there was a deal in which a dealer intended to sell a truck for, say, $50,000 and required a deposit of $10,000 by any hire purchaser. in the case of a $50,000 truck (a hypothetical example) the dealer knew the hire purchase company was going to have reservations about financing the full $50,000. `So the dealer draws up a hire purchase agreement anyway. The real price is still $50,000. But on the agreement the dealer said he had received the sum of $10,000 by way of deposit.' Mr Smith said that if a hire purchase company accepted the assignment of the agreement the dealer got his money in full and the customer got his truck (then claimed to be worth $60,000) without having to pay a deposit.
Notes: 1985? Apr? c12-24 Dom ?Evening Post - check date
